description: knife with an "S" shaped blade; gold and silver gilt handle with a zoomorphic head as the bolster; animal has an elephant trunk, horns that curve back and a mane; black metal mount
text: Threatening yet beautiful, ceremonial weaponry was used in advanced esoteric rituals to combat obstacles to enlightenment. The crescent blade derives from Indian butchers’ knives meant for removing the skin of an animal. An inscription on this chopper knife, whose crescent blade derives from the Indian butcher’s flaying knife, invokes the protective deity Mahakala Panjaranatha—who wields the weapon to slice through delusion and ignorance, separating illusion, or the “skin,” from ultimate reality. The handle takes the form of a vajra-- the thunderbolt representing instant enlightenment. The “Water Knife,” a name derived from the wave-like blade and hilt, holds similar power. In a tour de force of gold and silver metalwork, one sees the head of the makara (aquatic beast) taking the form of a composite animal, with an elephant’s trunk and tusk above, a crocodile head below, all with a flowing mane and tail in a cresting wave.
title: Vajra Water Knife
